Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery plate; glaze largely fired red-brown; interior: one wide band encircling black-figure decoration consisting of siren (only front remaining) to right with added red on body; dots, blobs, and incised blob rosette as filling ornament; on underside, black-figure decoration consisting of part of wing of siren or sphinx; foot glazed; on wall, parts of three rays.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Beazley 1944 / Groups of Early Attic Black Figure (p. 54, no. 89)
ABV / Attic Black-Figure Vase-Painters (p. 47, no.122) (Incorrectly labelled G522)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 351, no. B442)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0798) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 92, pl. I, no. 20)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
